item.title: Aortic Aneurysm
item.description: Aortic aneurysm is a localized, abnormal dilation of the aortic wall. Approx. 90% mortality if ruptures while not in surgery. Two main types: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) and Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm (TAA).

item.title: Appendisitis
item.description: Most common surgical emergency - highest incidence between 10-20 y/os Causes/Factors Gut organisms invade the appendix wall after lumen obstruction by lymphoid hyperplasia, faecolith or filarial worms

item.title: Cholecystitis

item.title: Hip Fractures
item.description: Fracture of the femur distal to the femoral head and proximal to a level 5 cm below the trochanter Intracapsular (within the capsule) - possible vascular compromise Extracapsular (outside the capsule) - 5 cm distal to lesser trochanter Inter-trochanteric Sub-trochanteric In elderly - occurrence of falls often signs underlying ill health

item.title: Lumps
item.description: Terminology Term Definition Abscess local accumulation of pus Bulla raised circumscribed lesion >5mm containing serous fluid (blister) above the dermis Comedone plug of dead epithelial material blocking pore: open (blackhead) or closed (whitehead) Erythema blanchable redness of the skin that can be localised or generalised (dilation of BVs and capillaries) Excoriation scratch which has broken the surface of skin Lichenification skin thickening with exaggerated skin markings as a result of repeated rubbing Macule flat well-defined area of altered skin pigmentation.

item.title: Melanoma
item.description: Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that originates from pigment-producing cells called melanocytes. It is known for its potential to metastasize (spread) to other parts of the body, making early detection and treatment crucial.

item.title: pancreatitis
item.description: Not an infective cause Acute damage can be temporary and can restore function ![[z_attachments/Pasted image 20231011141201.png|350]] Mild - swollen gland with fat necrosis Severe - swollen, necrotic gland and haemorrhage (Grey Turner’s and Cullen’s sign) Pseudocysts (full of pancreatic juice) Causes/Factors Gallstones (50%), alcohol (25%), idopathic (10%)

item.title: Squamous cell carcinoma
item.description: May begin as [[Lumps#Solar (actinic) keratosis|solar (actinic) keratosis]] or be found on the lips of smokers or long standing ulcers (Marjolin’s ulcer)

item.title: Surgical Site Infections
item.description: Prophylactic antibiotics are given to counter the risk of wound infection which occurs in ~20% of elective surgeries and up to 60% in emergency surgery

item.title: Varicose veins
item.description: Long, tortuous & dilated veins of the superficial venous system Blood from superficial veins of the leg pass into deep veins via perforation veins.
